title: Mayura Pirivena
text:
Mayura Pirivena ("Mayura" in <a href="Sinhala%20language">Sinhala</a>: <a href="peafowl">peacock</a>) is an ancient <a href="monastery">monastery</a> situated to the south-west of the <a href="Jaya%20Sri%20Maha%20Bodhi">Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi</a>, in <a href="Anuradhapura">Anuradhapura</a> in <a href="Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>.
One of the ancient <a href="chronicle">chronicle</a>s of Sri Lanka, the <a href="Mahavamsa">Mahavamsa</a>, states that this monastery was built by <a href="Buddhadasa%20of%20Anuradhapura">King Buddhadasa</a>, who ruled the island from 340 - 368 AD. King <a href="Dhatusena%20of%20Anuradhapura">Dhatusena</a> (455 - 477 AD) and King <a href="Mahanaga">Mahanaga</a> (573 - 575 AD) renovated the building. The Indian monk <a href="Buddhaghosha">Buddhaghosha</a> <a href="Thero">Thero</a> resided here during his stay in Sri Lanka.
The ruins of the structure still remain are few <a href="Rock%20%28geology%29">stone</a> <a href="column">column</a>s with <a href="capital%20%28architecture%29">capitals</a>, the <a href="gate">entrance</a> of the <a href="building">building</a> built above a few <a href="Stairs">steps</a> and a <a href="Sandakada%20pahana">moonstone</a> below these steps. In the middle of the moonstone, a half of the <a href="Nelumbo%20nucifera">lotus flower</a> can be seen.
According to a report issued by Mr. <a href="Harry%20Charles%20Purvis%20Bell">H. C. P. Bell</a>, the Archeological Commissioner of then <a href="British%20Ceylon">Ceylon</a>, this site was first excavated in 1894 and fallen pillars were lifted up. The report further states the length of the structure as and the width as . <a href="Excavation%20%28archaeology%29">Excavation</a> in the <a href="Location%20%28geography%29">location</a> was carried out in 2011 and the <a href="Archaeological%20site">site</a> was preserved in 2012.
